title: The Red Supergiant Progenitor of the Type II Supernova 2024abfl
authors:
Jingxiao Luo, Lifu Zhang, Bing-Qiu Chen, Qiyuan Cheng, Boyang Guo,
  Jiao Li, Yanjun Guo, Jianping Xiong, Xiangcun Meng, Xuefei Chen, Zhengwei
  Liu, Zhanwen Han
abstract:
Linkage between core-collapse supernovae (SNe) and their progenitors is not
fully understood and ongoing effort of searching and identifying the
progenitors is needed. $\mathrm{SN\,2024abfl}$ is a recent Type II supernova
exploded in the nearby star-bursting galaxy $\mathrm{NGC\,2146}$, which is also
the host galaxy of $\mathrm{SN\,2018zd}$. From archival Hubble Space Telescope
(HST) data, we have found a red source ($\mathrm{m_{F814W} \sim 25}$) near the
location (angular distance $\leq 0.2"$) of $\mathrm{SN\,2024abfl}$ before its
explosion. With F814W and F606W photometry, we found that the properties of
this source matched a typical red supergiant (RSG) moderately reddened by
interstellar dust at the distance of the host galaxy. We conclude that the
$\mathrm{SN\,2024abfl}$ had an RSG progenitor with initial mass of
$\mathrm{10M_{\odot}}$--$\mathrm{16\,M_{\odot}}$.
